channel.title: How Can i close an if statement?
channel.description: The problem wasn't the else if it was that it was reading all of then because I had all the items, so until I can find out how to stop running an of statement if the option is checked and the others aren't I will just have to have one item max in the bag for now - ps, thanks for the info, but this problem solution just occured to me, my first code was actually working fine ;)

item.title: How Can i close an if statement?
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“I Vain I”]I know this topic has already serveds it’s purpose, but I thought I’d inform you of a small mistake.

In your queries, you echo the player’s new item while attempting to show an image. By attempting, I mean you did it wrong.

You cannot , in most languages, encap a variable inside a String, which is what you did.

Here is a correct way of doing it.

echo ("<image src='images/items/'.$value.' alt='Equipment' /><br />"); I’m a bit rusty with encapping variables, so I’m not 100% as to whether I need an extra single-quote before the image’s alternative text.[/quote]
Uhh, in PHP you can just do what he did, just make sure to use double quotes…

Read full topic

item.source: How Can i close an if statement?

item.title: How Can i close an if statement?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

You should totally put those queries together, btw. SET wwield = ‘niggers’, inv2 = ‘other niggers’ WHERE username = ‘that one nigger’

You can also “nest” if-statements:

if (oneThing) {
if (oneThing1) {
} else if (oneThing2) {
} else {
}
} else if (secondThing) {
}

Read full topic
item.source: How Can i close an if statement?

item.title: How Can i close an if statement?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Something like this?
[php]
if ($inv1==‘Santa Hat’ or $inv1==‘Green Crown’ or $inv1==‘Gold Crown’)
{
$queryreg = mysql_query(“UPDATE users SET hwield = ‘$inv1’ WHERE username = ‘$username’”);
$queryreg = mysql_query(“UPDATE users SET inv1 = ‘$hat’ WHERE username = ‘$username’”);
echo (“You Are Now Wielding The Following Item:
“);
echo (”<img src=‘images/items/$value’
”);
die(“Return To Game.”);
}
else if ($inv2==‘Whip’)
{
$queryreg = mysql_query(“UPDATE users SET wwield = ‘$inv2’ WHERE username = ‘$username’”);
$queryreg = mysql_query(“UPDATE users SET inv2 = ‘$weapon’ WHERE username = ‘$username’”);
echo (“You Are Now Wielding The Following Item:
“);
echo (”<img src=‘images/items/$value’
”);
die(“Return To Game.”);
}
[/php]

You can have as many else-ifs as you want, but you might want to rethink your structure if you end up with a lot. The syntax is like this:
[php]
if(something == 1) {
echo “Something is 1”
} else if(something == 2) {
echo “Something is 2, not 1”
} else if(something == 3) {
echo “Something is 3, not 1 or 2”
} else if(something == 4) {
echo “Something is 4, not 1 or 2 or 3”
} else {
echo “Something is not 1 or 2 or 3”;
}
[/php]

[hr]

Wait I think I misunderstood your question. Are you saying that if $inv2 is ‘whip’ you don’t want to check the santa hat/crown stuff? If so, you just need to switch the blocks around in the above code so it’s like this:
[php]
if($inv2==‘Whip’)
{
$queryreg = mysql_query(“UPDATE users SET hwield = ‘$inv1’ WHERE username = ‘$username’”);
$queryreg = mysql_query(“UPDATE users SET inv1 = ‘$hat’ WHERE username = ‘$username’”);
echo (“You Are Now Wielding The Following Item:
“);
echo (”<img src=‘images/items/$value’
”);
die(“Return To Game.”);
}
else if ($inv1==‘Santa Hat’ or $inv1==‘Green Crown’ or $inv1==‘Gold Crown’)
{
$queryreg = mysql_query(“UPDATE users SET wwield = ‘$inv2’ WHERE username = ‘$username’”);
$queryreg = mysql_query(“UPDATE users SET inv2 = ‘$weapon’ WHERE username = ‘$username’”);
echo (“You Are Now Wielding The Following Item:
“);
echo (”<img src=‘images/items/$value’
”);
die(“Return To Game.”);
}
[/php]

Read full topic

item.source: How Can i close an if statement?

item.title: How Can i close an if statement?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

What does your code look like? Chances are both if statements return true.

Or:

if (condition) {
derp;
} else if (condition) {
herp;
}

if the first if-statement is true, it’ll forget about the second one. If it is false, it will attempt the second one.

Read full topic
